news.title: MetaMask Security Monthly: February 2023
news.subtitle: It‚Äôs a mixed bag this month. We‚Äôre happy to share what we‚Äôve been up to, but there are always threats out there. Whether you‚Äôre getting blasted by snow storms or relaxing on a sunny beach, we hope you enjoy our February report.

childMarkdownRemark.html:
Security Laboratory


Emmett Chappelle, renowned for his work in bioluminescence.

Endo


  • New approach to secure bundler - For the sake of plugging secure bundling into more existing bundlers in the ecosystem, the work gets split between two stages. One: a plugin to an existing tool (like webpack) to create a compartment map and transformed sources and save it as an app archive. Two: a bundler capable of turning an app archive into a secure bundle file. With that approach, adding support for a new bundling tool/ecosystem should require less work and be less likely to undermine the security aspects of the bundler. https://github.com/endojs/endo/pull/1449
  • Added attenuation for globals in policy. The basis for full compatibility with LavaMoat policies is ready for merging and shipping in compartment-mapper. A proof-of-concept attenuator implementing ‚Äòwrite‚Äô global policy was possible to introduce on top of that implementation. https://github.com/endojs/endo/pull/1491/

LavaMoat


  • Initial work on plugging into webpack to generate an Endo-compatible compartment map was started in https://github.com/LavaMoat/webpack-plugin-compartment-map
  • @lavamoat/snow Disabled creation of URL objects out of Blob/File to prevent bypass.

MetaMask Snaps


  • LavaMoat team helped with hardening functionality that‚Äôs exposed to MetaMask Snaps.
  • Research into unexpected iframe sandboxing side effects in Chrome.

The Good News


Eth_sign Disabled by Default; Toggle in Advanced Settings

MetaMask has observed a significant trend of phishing kits that abuse eth-sign to ask users to inadvertently sign malicious transactions. In the interest of striking an appropriate balance between user protection and user autonomy, MetaMask has disabled eth_sign by default but will allow you to toggle it back on in the advanced settings. You can read more about it in our extension PR.

Recently, Devin Shin, a technical support engineer for MetaMask, reported: ‚ÄúI was working with a user on a security ticket and wanted to share this. They provided me with an obvious scam site which I investigated. At first, I was confused as to the vector of phishing because nothing was happening while trying to interact with the site. I checked the console logs, and it was clear that the site attempted to prompt an eth_sign txn, which failed due to the recent change. Happy to see this change having a positive effect!‚Äù

Ding Dong, The Monkey Drainer is Dead! While we can‚Äôt say for certain, this change may have contributed to the end of the dreaded Monkey Drainer NFT phishing group.

Monkey Drainer has been shut down according to its owner. I wonder why ü§î pic.twitter.com/BZ06Y1staD

— Fantasy ü¶¢ (@0xFantasy) February 28, 2023

Update


üìß Namecheap/SendGrid Email Breach üé£

You may have received an email purporting to come from MetaMask a couple weeks ago, which asked users to enter their secret recovery phrases. You also might have seen our tweet warning about the high-profile phishing attempt, and reminding users MetaMask does not collect KYC info and will never email you about your account.

We have determined that the breach did not affect MetaMask directly, but the attackers were able to send MetaMask-branded phishing emails from the NameCheap domain. NameCheap initially stated that they believed the breach to have occurred with their upstream service provider, SendGrid. They later released the following statement on their blog, though both statements seem to have been withdrawn at the time of writing this on Feb 28.

Read more from Bleeping Computer.

Tales of Caution


Google Fi hack victim had Coinbase, 2FA app hijacked by hackers Another harrowing SIM swap tale. Cell phone provider Google Fi informed the user "hackers had stolen some customers‚Äô information, likely connected to the recent breach at T-Mobile." Things appear to have been resolved for now, but there are still many unanswered questions surrounding how safe this user's and other Google Fi customers' phones actually are. Read more from TechCrunch.

Fake Ethereum Denver website linked to notorious phishing wallet Don‚Äôt trust Google Ads! In the leadup to one of the biggest events in the Ethereum ecosystem, would-be EthDenver attendees were a prime target for scammers who went ‚Äúas far as paying for a Google advertisement to promote the malicious website‚Äôs URL.‚Äù Always be certain you know the authenticity of any source you connect your wallet to, and generally avoid any sponsored Google search results. Read more from Cointelegraph.

Beware of Social Engineering

1/ This week, an organised crime unit from Rome stole $4M from one of our users.

It was stated, the thief ‚Äòtook a picture‚Äô of the user‚Äôs Wallet balance to steal the funds.

We‚Äôve done investigating into the events and believe this is how it happened‚Ä¶üßµüëá

— Trust - Crypto Wallet (@TrustWallet) February 8, 2023

nodes.title: MetaMask feature update: Account Sync
nodes.subtitle: Giving you more configurability across your devices.

childMarkdownRemark.html:
MetaMask has released a new feature called Account Sync ‚Äî available now on browser extension, ahead of mobile wallet availability coming soon. Account Sync allows you to unify account names and addresses across a wallet that has the same Secret Recovery Phrase. Enabling this optional setting means that you no longer have to go in and manually edit details across different devices. Part of MetaMask Profile Sync functionality, users‚Äô data privacy is ensured through end-to-end encryption, preventing MetaMask, and anyone else, from viewing or accessing this information.

A wallet with the same Secret Recovery Phrase can:

  • Sync MetaMask Extension across Chrome/Brave browsers
  • Sync MetaMask Extension across desktops or laptops
  • Sync MetaMask wallet across Extension and mobile app
  • Sync MetaMask mobile apps across mobile devices
  • Sync MetaMask wallet after install

How to enable Account Sync

Existing users

  1. Go to Settings.
  2. Click on Privacy & Security.
  3. Turn on ProfileSync.

New users

Account Sync is turned on by default. To disable:

  1. Go to Settings.
  2. Click on Privacy & Security.
  3. Turn off ProfileSync.

How it works

Updates will be reflected when you lock/unlock or close/open MetaMask Extension. For example, if you have MetaMask open on two devices, and you add an account or rename an account on device A, you will need to close/open or lock/unlock MetaMask from device B for these changes to be reflected.

Synchronization details

  • If device A has more accounts than device B, MetaMask will add these additional accounts to device B.
  • The most recently re-named account will be synchronized across devices.
  • If you turn off Account Sync, account names and newly added accounts will start to vary across devices.
  • Re-enabling Account Sync will re-sync your devices.

In addition to Account Sync, MetaMask Profile Sync also includes Account Activity Notifications, with more features rolling out this year.

Head to MetaMask Portfolio to enable Account Sync ‚Äî for seamless account management across devices. Check out our profile privacy and security guide for more ways we protect and manage user data.

nodes.metaDescription: MetaMask's new Account Sync feature  allows you to unify account names and addresses across a wallet that has the same Secret Recovery Phrase.

nodes.title: MetaMask feature update: Gas Station
nodes.subtitle: Make running out of gas a thing of the past.

image.title: MetaMask feature update: Gas Station
image.description: MetaMask feature update: Gas Station image

childMarkdownRemark.html:
Being blocked by insufficient gas will no longer be a problem when swapping, thanks to MetaMask‚Äôs new Gas Station feature. Gas Station, aka gas-included swaps, is now available when you enable Smart Transactions with MetaMask Swaps.

Most web3 users have experienced running out of gas. If users do not have enough ETH balance to cover network fees, they cannot proceed with their transaction. When this happens, users must go through a time consuming, and often costly, on-ramping process, such as purchasing ETH on a centralized exchange, and transferring funds to their on-chain wallet. On-chain opportunities can be time-sensitive, and the on-ramping process can take hours.

With the rollout of Gas Station, our gas-included Swaps feature, users will be able to seamlessly and speedily complete their transactions ‚Äî with network fees included in the quote(s) they receive. Additionally, users will not be limited to any specific liquidity source for their Swaps, meaning we will still compare prices across the same wide variety of providers as we do today. Our Swaps feature combines data from decentralized exchange aggregators, market makers, and DEXs, to ensure you get competitive quotes with the lowest network fees.

Gas Station is live on MetaMask Extension via Ethereum mainnet, with mobile release on the horizon. Swaps value must be sufficient to also cover the cost of gas, and include the following assets: USDT, USDC, DAI, ETH, wETH, wBTC, wstETH, wSOL.

Head to MetaMask Portfolio today to get swapping. Looking for more? Dive into our recent updates here.

nodes.metaDescription: MetaMask's new Gas Station feature ‚Äî aka gas-included swaps ‚Äî now includes network fees in the quotes users receive.

nodes.title: Introducing MetaMask Signature Insights Snaps
nodes.subtitle: A new way to stay protected with community-powered tools.

childMarkdownRemark.html:
Safety is paramount in today's digital world ‚Äî especially in web3, where users frequently interact with decentralized applications and manage valuable assets. A common vulnerability in the ecosystem is malicious signature requests, which lead unsuspecting users to authorize transactions that compromise their assets. This can happen by tricking people into signing something that allows a nefarious actor to transfer a users‚Äô assets.

To address this critical safety issue, MetaMask has introduced Signature Insight Snaps, a new category of security tools built by third-party developers. These Snaps empower users with greater transparency and control over signature requests, helping to identify and avoid potential threats.

Signature Insight Snaps integrate seamlessly with MetaMask. These tools work by analyzing the contents of requests, giving users insights into the signature‚Äôs purpose and potential risks. Leveraging knowledge from Signature Insight Snaps allows users to make more informed decisions, reducing the likelihood of falling victim to phishing attempts, unauthorized access, or other malicious activities. The added layer of security reinforces users' trust, and also fosters a safer environment for web3 interactions.

Discover our first Signature Insights Snaps

Kleros Scout is the first Snap to support Signature Insights. It decodes the content of signature requests, and identifies the addresses of any contracts you may be authorizing in the signature via Kleros‚Äôs decentralized token curated registries. It can then warn you if the contract you are interacting with is malicious.

Above, the Kleros Scout insight is displayed in the new signature request design. The insight shows that the contract being authorized by this signature request is the official Seaport 1.6 contract for NFT trading deployed by OpenSea.

ZyFi Paymaster Insights is our second Signature Insight Snap to launch. It improves the readability of signing transactions in the zkSync ecosystem, especially for paymaster-related transactions using txType 113. ZyFi Paymaster Insights adds helpful information about the ‚Äúfrom‚Äù and ‚Äúto‚Äù addresses for these paymaster-related transactions. Additionally, it provides extra information related to the paymaster, such as the address, type, gas fee token address, and gas fee token amount. This gives users more clarity on what they‚Äôre signing, helping them to avoid potentially malicious signatures.

Above, the ZyFi Paymaster Insight shows the from address, to address, and the paymaster type of the signature request on zkSync.

Install Kleros Scout Snap and ZyFi Paymaster Insights from the MetaMask Snaps Directory in MetaMask Extension 12.4.2 or later.

Build your own

Visit the MetaMask Developer Documentation to learn how you can build your own Signature Insight Snaps, and sign-up for our Builder Engagement Program so we can support you on your developer journey.

In the future, Signature Insights Snaps will be able to hook into alerts in signature requests. MetaMask will also offer more types of insights including information about origin URL of any request.

Head to the MetaMask Snaps Directory to discover security Snaps that will keep you safe in your web3 journey.

nodes.metaDescription: Explore MetaMask Signature Insights Snaps, which help to safeguard web3 users from malicious signature requests.
